François De Roy died at the age of 75 years old. His collection was sold post mortem in May 1813

container-title: For late eighteenth- and nineteenth-century Great Britain there is Guido Guerzoni, ‘The British art market 1789-1914’, in Economic history and the arts
title: supraregional institutions such as Customs is rather striking. One of the few exceptions is the literature on the role of the British Customs in the boom of the auction market in the early 1690s. Iain Pears, The discovery of painting. The growth of interest in the arts in England 1680-1768 (New Haven
Ormrod, ‘The origins of the London art market’

When the Dutch Republic started levying import taxes in 1651, the ruler of the Southern Netherlands Philip IV of Spain responded by installing trade tariffs in 1654. General rules on import, export and transit of goods in the Southern Netherlands were only implemented in 1670 and 1680, which can be considered the start of a true Customs policy. Ilja Van Damme, ‘Het vertrek van Mercurius: historiografische en hypothetische verkenningen van het economisch wedervaren van Antwerpen in de tweede helft van de zeventiende eeuw’
